name: Chaser Enemies
intro: A tiny example for making a enemy chase the player.
author: KleistVisual

__comments: Here we have the timer that makes all the enemies move.
Now is each half second, because Pulp games work at 20 FPS.
We will use player_XY to compare positions using only one variable
Change the tile of the player depending on the last D-pad input
We are not using this in this example, but I'm leaving it here to remind
that you'll need to repeat this code in the enter event, because update it's not called
until you press any button (I think :D)
If we collected the sword, we can use it. I use it as an independent event
with the "call" function so I keep cleaner the "confirm" event
We get player's positions
Depending on player's facing we stablish the up, down, left or right tile of the sword
and we also change the coordinates where to draw the sword (the tile in front of the player)
Here we are telling the tile that is in front of the player
to call the event "die", when we attack. We are using it for killing the enemies
but this can be recycled for lots of things, like cutting plants.
A tiny delay so we can see the the sword. We need this because we are using
the varible "isAttacking" to tell if to draw or not the sword
This is a tiny custom event for when we are attacked with a cooldown for movement
and the "playerHitted" animation
We finally draw the sword while isAttacking is 1
This is the example of the code
without all the prefixes in the variables,
so it's easier to read :)
The tile you want to be "under" the enemy before the first movement
Later we use this variable to rememeber the previous tiles we swap everytime the enemy moves
This is not really neccesary, but i use it for making the
copy/pasting faster if I want to make more enemies
Check the "game" code. We are using "emit" to call this event in loop
Let's decide where to move
I'm using altMove to alternate between horizontal and vertical moves.
That way I prevent the diagonal move of the enemies,
and I also liked how it makes the enemies move, a little more messy/organic maybe?
This is the simplest way I could think to use a "greater-than/less-than" comparator in Pulp
And is basically what makes the enemy to decide to move towards the player
Remember the name of the destination tile
Check if the destination tile is solid
We make this to store the X and Y coordinates in the same variable
and compare it to the equivalent of the player later
If the destination is not solid, move the enemy
If the destination is not a "fakeWhite" tile, move
I use this to prevent enemies to go out of the screen
(You can check that this tile surrounds the edges of the room)
If the destination is not the player's position
Swap enemy position with the previousTile
Remember the destination tile as the prevTile for the future
Tell the destination to swap for our enemy
If player position = enemy destination, player gets hitted
Remember the name of the destination tile
Check if the destination tile is solid
If the destination is not solid, move the enemy
Swap in empty tile where the enemy was
Swap detination with enemy
Remember the name of the destination tile
Check if the destination tile is solid
If the destination is not solid, move the enemy
Swap in empty tile where the enemy was
Swap detination with enemy
Remember the name of the destination tile
Check if the destination tile is solid
If the destination is not solid, move the enemy
Swap in empty tile where the enemy was
Swap detination with enemy
Remember the name of the destination tile
Check if the destination tile is solid
If the destination is not solid, move the enemy
Swap in empty tile where the enemy was
Swap detination with enemy
